newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgaria debates 1997 budget, currency board plan.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria debates 1997 budget, currency board plan.

text.p: Bulgaria's cabinet has begun debating a 1997 budget designed to allow implementation of a tough monetary regime but has not yet approved a final draft, a government spokeswoman said on Tuesday.
"Late last night the cabinet debated a 1997 budget draft which involves introduction of a currency board plan but it came to no decision," a government spokeswoman told reporters.
The budget frame has not yet been finalised, she added, declining to elaborate.

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) proposed the introduction of a currency board to restore confidence in the lev, which has collapsed from 70 to the dollar at the start of the year to 500 on Tuesday.
Under the system the amount of levs in circulation must be matched with the central bank's hard currency reserves.
The currency board, whose adoption must be approved by parliament, halts central bank lending to the government, state enterprises and commercial banks.

Bulgaria has yet to debate to which currency and at what rate to peg the lev. The dollar is traditionally seen as a benchmark of stability, but some circles are lobbying for the mark, as Germany is the biggest investor in the country.
"Acceleration of inflation will depend very much on the rate at which the lev will be pegged," Vice President of Emerging Markets Research at Salomon Brothers David Boren told Reuters.
If the lev is pegged lower than the market rate, Bulgaria will remain competitive for a longer period and the local currency will appreciate, he said.
If the rate is closer to the current market rate it would be less painful when the currency board is implemented, but the lev would not retain its credibility over a longer period of time, he added.
IMF technical missions are currently in Sofia to help prepare the draft budget and the legal amendments needed to make the plan operational.

A preliminary draft prepared by the finance ministry three weeks ago envisaged a budget deficit of 370 billion levs or nine percent of gross domestic product (GDP), which is estimated at 4.054 trillion levs.
Expenditure was assumed at 1.46 trillion levs and revenue at 1.090 trillion levs.
GDP, which fell by 6.2 percent for the first half of this year, is seen falling a further 8.2 percent.

One of Bulgaria's options is to agree on a currency board implementation timetable with the IMF missions this month and make the necessary legal adjustments in the next one or two months and then introduce the currency board.
The alternative is to make the legal adjustments as soon as possible and introduce the plan in January, bankers said.
